ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Students met with professor on Zoom on a weekly basis (or more, depending on the team)
There were also abundant one on one meeting and discussions with the professor.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to effectively write a case study and develop my arguments clearly. I discovered new modes of research and was encouraged to constantly think deeper about the subject and how it connected to the larger project. It was an incredible semester and time learning how to synthesize my summer experience
This course was a continuation of GLBL 305 from the spring, in which students worked in their team to write a case study on the company they worked for over the summer of 2020.
Learning about thre social enterprise space and the challenges they face

I gained a strong understanding of business principles relevant to social enterprises as well as structural challenges to development in Africa. In addition, I was able to hone my case writing and research skills through the class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Bo is super engaging and willing to help. He was always available and excited to discuss the details of our case. He challenged me to be a better student and writer, as well as a more nuanced thinker. The only con was that it was a virtual experience and I know it would have been 10x better in person in class.
Strengths: Bo is a FANTASTIC professor and resource - he was incredibly helpful to my team, and was always willing to hop on a Zoom call (even on weekends and at any time of day).

The course is structured such that you are able to apply everything you learn from a summer experience and the previous semester of studying cases into case writing, which makes a lot of sense. The professor meets students on a flexible basis which is extremely helpful during case writing, and also provides a host of case writing resources and sample to assist students during the case creation process.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed the flexibility of this class and the ability to meet with my professor whenever, virtually.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! The year-long seminar was a wonderful experience. If you can take it in person, you definitely should
It is assumed you take this course after taking GLBL 305 (spring course) and completing your summer internship, so yes!

Yes I would absolutely recommend this course. Its a unique opportunity to engage with then reflect on a summer experience through case writing where you are able to practically apply and analyze concepts of development and business.
